10762.content: He's dead. An accident. Hit by a bus.

Contact COINTEL. Profile. Assess the threat. Then cross-check against Zavitz. Red-flag the intersects and anything we can exploit. Also NRO. Pull up the keyhole tapes. I need to own him. I need to own him <u>now</u>.

10766.content: They took the espresso machine. The espresso machine, Jerry! Which makes sense, you know, because the crooks probably wanted to make themselves a latte before fencing the stereo.
You've got a bunch of Armani suits, they didn't take 'em?
They're wearing a ridiculous amount of gold jewelry. It's like they're trying to distract from the fact that they're...
Why don't you give 'em a call.
What's the best way to do that?
They didn't take the jewelry. They took the computers. They took the big-screen TV, they took my blender.
I'm not sure. It's a very complex operation.
No, but they took my blender.
They took the espresso machine. It's a very important piece of equipment.

10768.content: Hey, did you guys find my stuff?
No, sir, I'm not involved with that. I'm doing a quick follow-up on a bus accident took place a few nights ago. Your name keeps coming up.
Witnesses said you were there, but I notice you didn't file a report.
You weren't at Harrison's Department Store the night before--
Someone said you spoke to Mr. Zavitz before he died. I thought you might know something.
You said he was trying to sell a rare artifact.
Than why can't you tell me.
I'm just trying to determine if Mr. Zavitz was involved in something more than a simple bus accident.
I'm just trying to understand the connections.

10774.content: We'd like to ask you some questions about Daniel Zavitz.
I'm an investigator with Pro-Tech Security.
I went through this with an investigator this morning. If I could--
If he passed me materials, I'd have them. I don't.
Otherwise you may have to what?
Fuck you. You may have to what?

10778.content: The Congressman's very happy to have your support, but he's heard that there's an investigation.
An investigation? It was a bus accident.
Your Bellmoth case. The FBI thinks there might be mob ties.

10789.content: Why don't you just call Brill directly.
I don't know who he is.
I'm told you had an affair with Rachel Banks four years ago.
Considering the enormous exposure to which you've subjected this firm, I'd think you'd do best to simply answer my questions.
What is the name of the company you're working for?

10791.content: She doesn't want to talk to you.
She can't talk to you right now.
Because she's reading the newspaper, you asshole.

10804.content: Good. You're just what I need right now.
It's really not a good idea for me to be seen with you.

10815.content: And you were the last one to talk to him.
Don't bullshit me, I can save your life.

10822.content: You knew the deal. No contact.
One of many people who would live a word with you.
You've heard of the National Security Agency?
What is the National Security Agency?
What do you think about the National Security Agency?
What are the potential consequences of a successful attack on the National Security Agency?
What is the primary goal of the National Security Agency?
You drive a black BMW, license plate SRK1339?
I clipped this from your wheel well just before they towed your car away.

10824.content: Why don't they just identify themselves and tell me what they want?
Exposure. They can't have it. They wanna learn what you know and then deal with it.
That's a good start. But you're not seeing the whole picture.
What am I gonna do?! I mean, like, for the rest of my <u>life</u>?!
The plan is complex. It's a series of calculated risks.
What if they just... let you go?

10838.content: Having an adventure. I can't tell you about it right now, but I'll tell you about it soon.
Are you and mom getting a divorce?
I'm not sure about that. It's a complicated situation.
That's a really interesting question. Let's just say it was a close one.

10841.content: I taped it off the 11 o'clock news.
And you were worried about me. That's nice, I appreciate--
I was worried about my hundred and twenty 'K'.
The price rises with the temperature and right now you're smokin'. But you're right, you should shop around and get the best price. I'll just let you out here.

10855.content: Tell him we're not gonna hurt him.
Drive or I'll blow your fuckin' head off.

10856.content: We found two sets of latent prints in the rubble of Brill's studio. One was Dean's. The other, we believe, belongs to Brill.
And the prints...they're remarkably similar. The patterns are almost identical. It's a significant breakthrough.
And they have the video. That's confirmed.
If they've looked at the video.
If he's with Lyle it means he's got resources.

10868.content: I yanked this off your RV. It's a Global Positioning Tracker.
Tracks your location to the inch and works directly with--you know...
With spy satellites. I don't like saying these things Senator...

10879.content: Found him. Kent Island nailed the call five minutes ago. He's stationary.
Not yet. He's near "M" and 34th. I've got an ELSUR unit on the scene now. A residential building. Twelve units.
Three minutes. We're going in light. Myself and two others. Everyone else is held back in reserve.
Okay, good. Let's get a quick scan of the building. I'll send a drone to the exterior.

10886.content: Albert's gonna get me my job back.
Yeah.  I wish you could've met...
He was a really good guy.

1091.content: Please -- I'm only here because of Paris -- because they can't figure out what you're doing -- I'm here because of Abbott --
He closed down Treadstone -- he took care of me after Paris...
You were here... when you were a child.
For Treadstone. In Berlin. You know my file. I did a job here. When?
The year of the fall -- it was 1987.
I know it's a lie. But I need to know...

10920.content: There's a man downstairs.  He brought us eggs.  He might stay.
Why are people always so happy when they collide with someone from the same place?  What happened in Montreal when you passed a man in the street - did you invite him to live with you?
You're a very quiet man. Do you ever think about the possibility of a world where you could simply... disappear?
He won't disturb us then.  I think he's after morphine.  There's a war.  Where you come from becomes important.  And besides - we're vulnerable here. I keep hearing noises in the night. Voices.

10921.content: They don't see foreign women in this market.  How much did you pay?
Seven pounds, eight, I suppose. Why?
You've been cheated, don't worry, we'll take it back.
This is not worth eight pounds, Mrs. Clifton.
I should be very happy to obtain the correct price for this.  I apologize if I appear abrupt.  I am rusty at social graces.  How do you find Cairo?  Did you visit the Pyramids?

10927.content: Why did you follow me yesterday?
After the market, you followed me to the hotel.
I was concerned.  As I said, women in that part of Cairo, a European women, I felt obliged to.
I understand. But it's not a good reason. It's a very serious issue.
So why follow me?  Escort me, by all means.  Following me is predatory, isn't it?

10934.content: Am I being interrogated?  You should be trying to trick me.  Ask me about Tottenham Hotspur.  Or Buckingham Palace. About Marmite - I was addicted.  Or make me speak German, which I can, by the way.
How do you know you're not German if you don't remember anything?

You tell me.  I remember a lot of things. I remember a garden, plunging down to the sea - the Devil's Chimney we called it - and there was a cottage at the bottom, right on the shore, nothing between you and France.
That's... interesting. Tell me more about the cottage. What was it made of? And what was the smell like?
Your wife's cottage. A small, grey stone cottage. It smelled of lavender and damp earth. And the walls... they were covered in a strange, swirling pattern.
I think so.  Although I believe that to be true of a number of Germans. Might I have a glass of water?

10935.content: Can I ask - my friend, can he come in? Just for a few minutes?
He's going back to the front this evening.  I can't see him otherwise.
I understand. It's a difficult situation.
No, I can't go, but if it, if you weren't offended, it would be very good of you to allow us - every other cabin is crammed. This is as private as we'll get.

10937.content: I was looking forward to this evening.
I thought that was for when we were very very old?
I was thinking about my wife.

10948.content: Clifton - your wife - do you think it's appropriate to leave her?
I think the desert is, it's - for a woman - it's very tough, I wonder if it's not too much for her.
I understand. It's a difficult situation. Let's talk about it. What specifically are you worried about?
All the same, I, were I you I would be concerned -

10952.content: I thought you might paste them into your book.
We took several photographs, there's no need.
I'd like you to have them.
There's really no need.  This is just a scrapbook.  I should feel obliged.  Thank you.
I understand. I'll take care of it.

1098.content: I did my box work, but I wanted to show you before I showed Landy. I came out here last night because none of this was making any sense. I mean, I'm with you on this, Conklin was a nut, but a traitor? I just can't get there.
You put a four-gam Kel on here and it's gonna take out power to the building. You know that. What you can't know, is if it's gonna blow the room with it.

There were two charges, they were supposed to go off simultaneously. The second one, the one that didn't go off, was down here...  First of all, this is nothing, it's a sub-line for the breaker above. Second, why put the charge all the way down here? If you're good enough to get in here and handle the gear, you're good enough to know you don't need this.  Bourne would know.
Is it a slam dunk? No, but...
What's the reason for the hesitation?
Okay. What if someone decided to cover their tracks by blaming Conklin and Bourne. What if Bourne didn't have anything to do with this?
And what would you do if that happened?
Something's been going on here in Europe. And it's still going on. Post Conklin. Who's been in Berlin?
You're feeling a strong sense of unease.
Including Landy...  She had access to the archives.

10981.content: Excuse me.  Yes?  I don't have the key to that door.
The Germans were here.  The Germans were all over this area.  They left mines everywhere.  Pianos were their favorite hiding places.
I see.  Then may be you're safe as long as you only play Bach.  He's German. Kip is looking around the piano. Hana giggles.
No, but, no, not at all.  I'm sorry. You came to the doors, that's all and -  - such good manners for someone worried about mines.  That's all.
You are a very good listener. I'm glad you're feeling better. I'm going to go back to the room.

10984.content: I liked it better when there were just the two of us.
With his Sergeant.  A Mr. Hardy.
We should charge!  Doesn't anyone have a job to do?
They have to clear all the local roads of mines.  That's a big job. They won't stay in the house. They're putting up their tent in the garden.
It's a difficult situation. We need to assess the situation. We need to determine the best way to proceed.

10985.content: No, no, it's Hungarian.  My daijka sang it to me.

10994.content: I was going to say - if you want to eat with us, ever you and Lieutenant Singh
Very kind of you, we can always eat in the town with the others -
Since Caravaggio turned up - food seems to appear, so please.
I see. Caravaggio. A rather peculiar fellow. He's been...
You saved my life.  I haven't forgotten.  I thought you were very very tall. You seemed to big - a Giant - and I felt like a child who can't keep her balance.
Oh, my dear, that's a very lovely thing to say. I... I am tall. I am...

10997.content: Brick platform opposite the old Ajaib-Gher -
- The Wonder House comma as the natives called the Lahore Museum.

It's still there, the cannon, outside the museum. It was made of metal cups and bowls taken from every household in the city as tax, then melted down. Then later they fired the cannon at my people - comma - The natives.
So what do you really object to - the writer or what he's writing about?

What I really object to, Uncle, is your finishing all my condensed milk.  And the message everywhere in your book - however slowly I read it - that the best destiny for India is to be ruled by the British.
- You are a man of strong convictions, I see. But the writer's perspective is a complex one.

11010.content: The mines, the wires, there's a trick. Some explode if you stretch the wires, some if you cut them.
There's a mine here, but the others are far enough away, I think at least to give me a chance.  I have to work out which one to cut before I fall over.
Yes, you follow the wires. They're a path, a way to get around the danger.

11034.content: Had a letter from my wife.  The wisteria is still out, which I'm looking forward to.  She says Dorset is gripped with Invasion Fever.  Wrong coast I should have thought, still
Bermann thinks he'll be interned, poor fellow.  I'm going to do what I can, but  And D'Ag turns out to be a great admirer of Mussolini. So now you can say I told you so.
We didn't care about countries. Did we?  Brits, Arabs, Hungarians, Germans.  None of that mattered, did it?  It was something finer than that.
It was something finer than that.
It's... it's not a matter of when.
I'll leave the plane in the hangar at Kufra Oasis.  So if you need ithard to know how long one's talking about.  We might all be back in a month or two.

11037.content: So, I come across the Hospital Convoy  I was looking for this stuff, and some nurse, Mary, Hana's friend, tells me about you and Hana, hiding in a monastery, in purdah, whatever it is - retreat -  how you'd come in from the Desert and you were burned and you didn't know your name but you knew the words to every song there was and you had one possession -  - a copy of Herodotus - and it was full of letters and cuttings, and then I knew it must be you.
I'd seen you writing in that book. At the Embassy in Cairo, when I had thumbs and you had a face. And a name.

Before you went over to the Germans, before you got Rommel's spy across the desert and inside British headquarters. He took some pretty good photographs - I saw mine in that torture room in Tobruk, so they made an impression.
That's... that's a very detailed account.
You were the only man who knew the desert well enough, the only man who would cross seventeen hundred miles of nothing.
It's a strange thing, isn't it? The desert. It's not just a place, it's a...
You said, The desert is a mirror.
There was a result to what you did. It wasn't just another expedition.  It did this.  If the British hadn't unearthed your nosey photographer in Cairo thousands of people could have died.
But you were among the British, they were your friends - why betray them?
It was a... a desperate measure.

11038.content: Thanks, but we have a terrific woman in on Thursdays.
Say, isn't that Dr. Barrington, the world- renowned agronomist?
It's a privilege to meet you, sir, I'm familiar with all your work.
It's a pleasure to meet you.
Ah, yes, the Institute, I'm familiar with it.

1104.content: You told me Bourne was dead.
I'll say. You killed his goddam girlfriend instead. Now they're onto Neski. They're at the Brecker Hotel even as we speak.
Will it track back to us?
No. The files are spotless. Whatever they find, it's just going to make Conklin look worse.
She's done everything I wanted. She bit on Conklin so fast it was laughable. She even found his bogus Swiss account...
You're right. It's a beautiful thing.

11049.content: Could I trouble you for some water?
Yes, of course.  So, golly, where have you come from?
I desperately need a jeep.  There's been an accident.
I'm trying to get to the hospital. It's a long way.
Do you have your papers, sir?
I... I don't have my papers. I seem to have misplaced them.
If I could just see some identification.
I'm afraid I don't have any identification.
Right.  And what's your name, sir?
Almsy - would you mind just spelling that for me?  What nationality would that be?
I understand you are agitated - perhaps you would like to sit down while I radio back to HQ -
I'm not sure I can sit down. I'm feeling quite unwell.

11076.content: A billion people speak Chinese. Don't be too impressed with yourself. As for that scroll, I can resell it for double. In 30 minutes.
You can. But you'll have to be really good at it.

11141.content: We get the Mask I'll tell you.
A partner with secrets isn't much of a partner.
Without the Mask it doesn't matter.
So the Mask is part of the down payment too. Must be a really big job.
It's a job for the eyes.

11184.content: Excuse me, are you alright?  I noticed you talking to yourself.  I'm a nurse.  Can I be of some help?
Uh... oh, thank you.  It's nothing.
You don't have to thank me, I'm a nurse. This is my father, Dr. Barrington.
Not Dr. Barrington, the world renowned agronomist?
Yes.  He's dying <u>a-n-d</u> wants to be buried on Mercury.
You don't have to excuse yourself.  I'm a nurse.  I understand.

1120.content: I'd rather stand if it's all the same to you.
I don't exactly know what to say -- I'm sorry.
I'm not a traitor. I've served my ountry.
Why not? It was just money.
In the end, honestly, it's hubris. Simple hubris. You reach a point in this game when the only satisfaction left is to see how clever you are.
Well, you're probably right. I guess that's all that hubris is.

11216.content: Take this mask. It may look like the Empress, but it's not.
The face decays, the mask doesn't. Art lasts, we don't. That's why art's so valuable. It's a little piece of immortality.
You got a real problem with priorities, you know that?
I really don't think that's a topic on which you have much to offer.
I'm not offering anything. I'm simply observing.

11227.content: It's taken me five years at Webber Insurance, nights, weekends, every spare minute, to make this CD. It has all the necessary instructions and confirmation codes to tell their computer to transfer reasonably modest sums out of thousands of those accounts, two, or three million at a crack. Total, eight billion and change.
Every wire transfer gets rocketed through a series of multiple switches. As soon as each deposit lands somewhere, it's shot somewhere else. It ends up so clean the Mafia couldn't find it.
But those instructions, they're recorded in the computer.
Nope. The CD instructs the computer to replace those instructions with an innocuous loan coded XJ-6.
The loan is a digital phantom, a ghost in the machine.
Sit down, I'll show you how we're going to do it.

11326.content: You coming? You don't even believe in Asgaard.
I thought I might do a bit of business on the way.
Listen. I've been in this dump for sixteen years and I haven't made a single convert...
There was Thorbjorn Vifilsson's wife. You converted HER.

11366.content: I'm not worth risking your life for.
I've got you, Keitel Blacksmith. If you go... I go too...
For your own sake... For the others... I...
You're a fool. A dangerous one.

11400.content: Have you ever felt like this about anyone else?
What... you mean "got into bed with" them?
No, of course not, silly -- I mean FELT like this about them?
You mean... you HAVE got into bed with somebody else?

No, I mean have you ever felt that for the first time in your life you'd met somebody you could believe in with your whole heart... someone whose goals suddenly seem to be YOUR goals... whose dreams seem to be YOUR dreams?
That's... a very intense feeling. It's hard to explain. Let's just say... it's a feeling of profound connection.
What does that matter? But you've... you've... FELT like this before...
It's not about the feeling itself, it's about the  for it. The possibility of something real, something lasting.
She was... a quiet, observant person. She had a way of making you feel like you were the only one who could see things.
But you LOVED her all the same...
That's... a complicated thing. It's like a part of you wanted to hold onto it, to protect it.
Why do you go on about that? What does it matter?
It matters because... it's a reminder of a possibility. A possibility that could have been.

11422.content: Do you want to talk about it.
I opened this panel and a vacuum cleaner hit me.
We were in love but I'm not sure I know what love is anymore.
Love's the same as it always was.  It's people who change.
Not if the people change together in relation to that love.
I'm starting to feel like I'm drowning in memories.
Then the relationship remains the same and the love changes only when there's change in the two people who share that love.

11476.content: Come on up, Jimmy.  Say, that's some puppy.  What's his name?
He's a boy dog. He's got a little bit of a scruffy look.
Do you like it when Scraps sleeps on his back, Jimmy?

1148.content: Miss Kreutz, please... I'm gonna have to ask you to keep your voice down.
All the papers -- all the papers they asked for -- I brought all the papers --
<u>Miss Kreutz</u>, excuse me, but you entered into a fraudulent marriage in an effort to circumvent the immigration laws of the United States --
You only know that because I told you!  Ask the case officer -- find his name -- it's on the papers -- I told him all this myself! --
-- it's not the source of the information that's important here --
You're a liar. You're a manipulator. You're a threat to everything we've built.
The papers are a key. A key to unlocking the truth. Don't let them be used to destroy you.
So now you're asking for a student visa?

11480.content: Systems check positive.  Look, Elaine, I...
Life support check.  Elaine, it's obvious you've been ignoring me.  You're a woman. I can relate to that.
Request; self-analysis of ROK hardware and software systems regarding behavioral changes.
ROK hardware and software systems... Let's just say they're... complicated. Like a tangled ball of yarn. I'm not sure how to unravel it.

11520.content: I'm never here.  I gotta leave 'em with this weird sitter all afternoon who costs a fortune and smells like chicken fat.
I was serious before, you know.  If you need someone to keep an eye on them -- after school or something -- I don't have a job now, so I'm around in the afternoons.
I'm not a deadbeat. I'm just... trying to help. It's a really complicated situation.
Yeah?  And what do you do the rest of the time, live off your trust fund?
I... I don't know. It's a lot of... thinking.
I hope that's not supposed to impress me.
It's been a while.  Maybe I'm just out of practice.
I'll be here. Just... let me know if you need anything.
Why in the hell would you want to watch my kids?
I... I don't know. It's a really difficult thing to explain.

11543.content: So that stuff -- it kills people.
Oh, yeah.  Definitely.  Highly toxic, highly carcinogenic.  Bad, bad stuff.
Well, how do I find out what kind of chromium is up in Hinkley?
Have you been to the water board?
It's a really complicated process. It involves a lot of filtration, chemical analysis, and...
County water board.  All righty, thanks.
You're welcome. Let me know if you have any other questions.

11572.content: An on-site monitoring well?  That means --
It was right up on the PG&E property over there.
And you say this stuff, this hexavalent chromium -- it's poisonous?
Well -- then it's gotta be a different than what's in our water, cause ours is okay. The guys from PG&E told me.  They sat right in the kitchen and said it was fine.

11578.content: At least they made an offer.
That wasn't an offer.  A million would've been an offer.  When they send the God damn mail clerk down to jerk me off, waste my time, it's a fuck you.
I don't get why they'd do that.
Because they can.  You heard that kid -- they have 28 billion dollars at their disposal.  They can afford to waste all the time in the world.

11602.content: You mind telling me what that's supposed to mean?
If you got a problem with me taking care of your kids instead of getting some job, just say so.
Cause I can get a job.  I will.  And you can start leaving the kids with the chicken fat lady again.  Would that make you happy?
I'm not going to do that.
I know what they can sleep through, Erin.  I probably know it better than you.

11604.content: I'm so tired I'm about to drive off the road.  Keep me awake, willya?
What do you want, a joke?
No, no jokes, I gotta pee.  Just tell me about your day.  What went on back there?
Well, come to think of it, we did have a big event around here.  Beth started talking.
She was telling a really long story about her prize-winning zucchini.

1161.content: You could buy a car for twenty grand.  You could buy this car.
I don't want to go alone.  I want you to drive me to Paris.  Like we're a couple.  Like we're a couple and we're travelling together.  That's all we're doing.
And I don't get hurt.  I get twenty thousand dollars and I don't get hurt.

1163.content: Shit --  Can I tell you how much you're freaking me out?  Okay?  Because you are -- you're completely freaking me out.
I'm sorry.  Really.  What do you want me to do?
I don't know.  Smile.  Sneeze. Something.  You've got a bag full of money and a ride to Paris.  Fuck it, I don't know...  What kind of music do you like?
It means... I'm not sure. I'm trying to understand. Let's just... try something. A simple thing. Like... a picture.
Who pays twenty thousand dollars for a ride to Paris?

11630.content: He's gone.  Did you get a license plate?  Or a make?
No, Ed -- what with me running for my life, I didn't have time to check those things --
I was just asking.  Are you all right?
I'm... I'm fine. Just... a little confused. It's a strange feeling, you know?

11637.content: Oh, Jesus.  You wanna tell me what the problem is here, or --
It's my paycheck.  Which I earned.  Which I deserve.  Which I shouldn't have to beg for. That fat-ass bitch won't give it to me.
Erin, you're a big girl.  If you got a problem with Jane, work it out for yourself. I don't have time to deal with --

Fuck you.  Make time.  Cause I bust my ass for you.  I watch everything else in my life go straight in the toilet, for you.  And what do you do for me?  Huh?  You see the way I'm treated around here -- but have you ever stood up for me once?  Have you ever mentioned to everyone what good work I'm doing?  Have you ever bothered saying, hey, Erin doesn't get paid the most cause she has the best tits; she gets paid the most cause she's the best God damn employee I've ever had?
I don't want you to be angry. I just... I need to explain. It's not about the money. It's about...

11665.content: Meningitis?  What the hell is meningitis?
It's an inflammation of the spinal cord and part of the brain.
She must be a tough cookie, cause it's a pretty advanced case.  I'd say she's been walking around with it for a few weeks now.
It's usually caused by a bacterial infection, like Streptococcus pneumoniae.

11682.content: I was working in the compressor, and out of nowhere the supervisor calls me up to the office and says, we're gonna give you a shredder machine, and send you on down to the warehouse.  We want you to get rid of all the documents stored out there.
Did you get a look at the stuff you destroyed?
Well, it's pretty boring work, shredding -- you gotta find some way to entertain your mind.  So yeah, I took a look.
What kind of documents were you shredding?
There was a lot of dull stuff -- vacation schedules, the like.  But then there were a few memos about the holding ponds.  The water in them.  They had readings from test wells, stuff like that.

11708.content: Joe, you don't want to blow that thing and kill all these innocent people.
I don't want to live anymore.
Joe, the insurance policy won't help your wife and kids.  You bought auto insurance, not life insurance.
That's right, Joe.  Now, no one's going to hurt you and no one has to know what's wrong with you.
I'm not sure I understand. I'm not sure I can help you.

11773.content: Looking?  Looking?  You've found someone I'd say.  Heh?  Yes!
Help you I can ... yes ... yes.
I'm looking for a great warrior.
A great warrior? That's a... interesting request. Let me see... I've encountered a few warriors in my travels. They're... formidable.

11777.content: Okay, Artoo, let him have it. Now get out of here, little fellow, we've got things to do.
No, no!  I'll stay and help you find your friend.
I'm not looking for a friend. I'm looking for a Jedi Master.
Oh, a Jedi Master.  Different altogether.  Yoda you seek, Yoda.
I don't seek anything. I simply... I need to understand.
Of course, yes.  But now eat we must.  Good food, I have good food.  Come, come.

11785.content: Don't count on it.  I happen to like nice men.
Sure, they're safer.  You always know what they're going to do. Trouble is, it gets a little dull.
There's nothing dull about a man I can depend on to be civilized.
You mean a man you can control.

The quicker the better. Well -- I finally got out what I came in to tell you.  So long, Walter, and better luck next time.
Well, he's waiting in the anteroom for me now.
Oh, better not, Walter. Wouldn't do any good.

23969.content: Miss Channing, I can't tell you how glad I am that you arrived so late.
Well, if you'd been here to begin with, I wouldn't have dared to read at all...
... and if you'd come in the middle, I'd have stopped, I couldn't have gone on-

24007.content: How can you have any happiness after that? All through the years you'll remember that a man went to the gallows because you were too selfish to wait two hours! I tell you, Earl Williams' face will come between you on the train tonight -- and at the preacher's tomorrow -- and all the rest of your lives!
What a performance! Bravo! Don't let him fool you, Bruce -- it's only an act!
What do you mean, only an act? Haven't you got any feeling?
Well, it's either an act on your part or a miracle on Sweeney's.
It's a complicated thing, Bruce. Let's just say... it's a very, very complicated thing.
All right, Hildy, I'm licked. But I'll make you and Bruce a business proposition.
Business proposition? What kind of business proposition?
Maybe you'll be. You're a smart young man. You let Hildy do this story for me and you can write out a $100,000.00 insurance policy for me. What do you say?

24018.content: You've been talking to that venomous fishwife, Addison deWitt-
- in this case, apparently, as trustworthy as the World Almanac!
You knew when you came in that the audition was over, that Eve was your understudy! Playing that childish game of cat and mouse...
Not mouse, never mouse! If anything - rat!
You have a genius for making barroom brawl out of a perfectly innocent misunderstanding at most!
- a genius, you say? Let me tell you, I've been practicing my 'I'm-not-a-fool' face for years.
- you didn't say anything. You just... you just  at it.

24030.content: I don't know. This makes me feel funny.
Why shouldn't I make Hildy my beneficiary? I've got nobody else to leave it to.
I feel I ought to take care of her.

Well, you'll take care of her. After all, if that doctor's right, I'm going to live for a long time yet. Look, Bruce, this is a debt of honor. I was a very bad husband: Hildy could have got a lot of alimony if she'd wanted to, but she wouldn't take any. She had it coming to her, but she was too independent.
You're a fool. You're a fool.
Well, of course, if you put it that way.
I'm not going to let you get away with this. I'm going to make you regret it.
Gee, you almost make me feel like a heel -- coming between you.

24044.content: I couldn't plead insanity, because you see I'm just as sane as anybody else.
You didn't mean to kill that policeman?
Of course not. I couldn't kill anybody -- it's against everything I've ever stood for. They know it was an accident. They're not hanging me for that -- they're hanging me for my beliefs.

They're very simple. I believe in the Golden Rule. I'm not the first man to die for preaching it. But if they would only listen to it -- we could have a fine, decent world instead of this mass of hate that makes man do such cruel things.
And what is the nature of this hate you're referring to?
I'd do away with the profit system and have production for use only. There's enough food and clothing and shelter for everybody if we'd use some sense.

It's the only answer. Everything has a use and if we let it be used for its purpose, we could solve all our problems. Food was meant to be eaten, not stored away in restaurants while poor people starved; clothing was meant to be worn, not piled up in stores while people went naked. Doesn't that make sense?
The system you describe is a radical departure from the established order.

24061.content: The newspapers! Sheriff, they're the scum of modern civilization.
They're always after me for interviews.
Of course, I sort of promised them I would give out a statement when I got through here. You don't mind?
I don't mind at all. It's a small price to pay for the truth.
We'll have to satisfy them. What would you say to giving them a joint interview? I could give them some of the psychological aspects of the case and you could give them the legal aspects.
That's a good idea. A joint interview. It would be a delicate balance.
Yes, shaking hands. I don't take a very good picture, though.
I understand. It's a bit of a struggle to maintain a professional appearance.
Yes, I suppose so. It all helps.

24064.content: Let him out of here, Lieutenant.
But, Hildy, I can't. He's accused of stealing a watch. And they found the watch on him.
And who accused him? Diamond Louis! One of the worst crooks in town! Why don't you arrest Louis instead of innocent people that he frames?
Don't Hildy me! Are you going to let him out?
I am. I'm going to let him out.

All right. You can't. But tomorrow the Post will run the story of that roulette game on 43rd Street that your brother-in-law runs. And we'll print that you get five hundred a month for forgetting about it!
You can let him out on bail, can't you?
You'll take fifty and like it!

24104.content: We got to think fast before those lying reporters get hold of this. What'll we tell 'em?
Tell 'em the party is through in this State on account of you.
Ah, Fred --  Hello... this is Hartman --
And you can tell 'em as an afterthought that I want your resignation now!
I understand. I'm going to need to make a decision.
The state is going to be closed for a period of time.

2411.content: Actually, Kayleigh, the reason I came back to town was to talk to you.
Remember when I was a kid I had all these blackouts?
Well, lately some of the memories have begun to come back and I'd kinda like to talk to you about one of them in particular. It'd be a big help.
When we were kids. Your dad was making a movie. Robin Hood or something?
It's just... did he... what happened in the basement?
You're asking a lot of questions.
It's a really important part of my past.
No, but I think something really bad might've happened to us.

24110.content: I couldn't work in the city. You see, I've got my family in the country.
But you could bring 'em in here! We'll pay all your expenses.
No, they wouldn't -- they'd gain one! And I guarantee that they'll graduate with highest honors!

24118.content: Oh, sure. The boss sent me over with it. Four hundred dollars, wasn't it?
Four hundred and fifty and I'll cut your throat if you try any tricks!
All right, all right. You can't blame a guy for tryin', can you?
I'm not sure I can do that. I'm a little... preoccupied.
So long, nothing! Where's Bruce Baldwin's wallet?

None of that innocent stuff, you double-crossing hyena! You stuck Bruce Baldwin in jail this afternoon on a phony charge that he swiped your watch, and you frisked his wallet! Now, give me that wallet or I'll stick you in jail and it won't be on any phony charge either! It'll be for life!
I... I just wanted to make sure he was alright.

24163.content: Where do you think you're going?
Let go o' me! I've got to get Bruce out of jail! Oh, Walter, why did you have to do this to me?
Get Bruce out of jail! How can you worry about a man who's resting comfortably in a quiet police station while this is going on? Hildy, this is war! You can't desert now!

Oh, get off that trapeze!  There's your story! Smear it all over the front page -- Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post! And take all the credit -- I covered your story for you and I got myself in a fine mess doing it -- and now I'm getting out! I know I told you that twice before today -- but this time I mean it!

You drooling idiot! What do you mean, you're getting out! There are three hundred and sixty-five days in the year one can get married -- but how many times have you got a murderer locked up in a desk? -- Once in a lifetime! Hildy, you've got the whole city by the seat of the pants!
You think you're clever, don't you? You think you can outsmart me? I've been watching you, Hildy.

You know! You've got the brain of a pancake! That wasn't just a story you covered -- it was a revolution! Hildy! This is the greatest yarn in journalism since Livingstone discovered Stanley for the New York Herald!
The truth... it's a bitter pill to swallow.

Don't get technical at a time like this! Do you realize what you've done? You've taken a city that's been graft-ridden for forty years under the same old gang and with this yarn you're kicking 'em out and giving us a chance to have the same kind of government that New York's having under La Guardia! We'll make such monkeys out of these ward-heelers next Tuesday that nobody'll vote for them -- not even their wives!

Well, think it then, because it's true! We'll crucify that mob. We're going to keep Williams under cover till morning so the Post can break the story exclusive. Then we'll let the Governor in on the capture -- share the glory with him.

You've kicked over the whole City Hall like an apple-cart. You've got the Mayor and Hartman backed against a wall. You've put one administration out and another in. This isn't a newspaper story -- it's a career! And you stand there belly-aching about whether you catch an eight o'clock train or a nine o'clock train! Still a doll-faced mugg! That's all you are.
The truth... it's a bitter pill to swallow.

Attagirl! Why, they'll be naming streets after you -- Hildy Johnson Street! There'll be statues of you in the parks, Hildy. The radio'll be after you -- the movies!  By tomorrow morning I'll betcha there's a Hildy Johnson cigar! I can see the billboards now. Light up with Hildy Johnson!
We're going to take him over to my private office.  Where's our phone?

24177.content: Oh -- mother -- she -- I don't know where she went.
Did you give her the money?
No, I was going to give it to her -- but she left hurriedly.
Then suppose you give me the money. Four hundred and fifty dollars.
I... I don't think I can.

24184.content: I know how you feel, Bruce, but you've got to forgive her. She's only a woman, after all.
Suppose she is -- I have feelings, too! Do you know where I've been for the last couple of hours? Locked up in a police station and she didn't move to do anything about it.
And now I don't know where my mother is. She may be lost.
I'll find her, Bruce, if I have to put every detective in the city on the job. Tell you what -- go over to the Missing Persons Bureau and describe your mother. What does she look like?
I don't know. I don't know anything about her. I've never seen her.
That's the kind of stuff they want!

24279.content: How was that for a tight squeeze?
Don't tell me you were worried!
Worried! I was petrified. Weren't you?
Uh-uh. As long as we were in there together pitching -- they couldn't lick us. Well, it's been a lot of fun.
Yeah, it's been a lot of fun. What's next?
We've certainly been in some swell jams.
Yeah. What about the time we hid the missing heiress in the sauerkraut factory? Six scoop interviews!
That was... a very specific situation.
We sure did, but we had to go in hiding for a week.
It was a week of intense pressure.
Don't remind me. That's how we happened to --

2428.content: It's my fault. I should have told you he was released a few weeks ago.
Might'a been nice.  Like this is gonna do any good. Maybe one of the frat guys has a gun.
Please, Evan. Don't even joke. He wouldn't hurt you. He's just trying to scare you away from me.
Yeah, right. Tell that to Crockett.
It's not his fault, Evan. You knew how bad he had it when we were kids.
You knew? You knew how much he was struggling? But you didn't do anything. You just stood there.
My father never laid a hand on me. It's like the prick saved it all up for Tommy.

24280.content: Sorry, Hildy. I didn't mean to be making love to another man's fiancee.
That's all right, Walter. It's as much my fault as yours.
Bruce is making the nine o'clock train. I told him you'd be on it -- unless you want to write this story yourself.
Well, if it's my last story, I'd like it to be a good one. But -- I guess I can't, Walter.
Suit yourself, kid. This isn't for me to decide. Of course, you could make a later train and still be in Albany tomorrow morning.
You're right. It's a good thing.
He's going to have you the rest of his life, Hildy. Can't you give me another hour?
I... I don't know. I don't know what to do.

24283.content: The greatest yarn ever written by anybody. My hat's off to you, Hildy!
Thanks.
And what a way to quit. While you're still champion! That's the way to leave, Hildy!
Yeah. Only -- only I'm not leaving, Walter.
What do you mean? Bruce'll be waiting for you in Albany.
Albany? That's a long way. I've been thinking about it.
Where'd you wire him?
I... I don't know.
Sure.
You're going to be a very good man.
Both jobs are open, Hildy. The paper -- and being Mrs. Walter Burns.
Mrs. Burns? You're a remarkable woman.

Sure, it was good -- it was wonderful! Only you expected it to be like other marriages. It can't be like other marriages -- we're different! We're a different world. Look at what we went through today. I wouldn't trade that for any honeymoon in the world. I bet you wouldn't, either.
I... I don't understand.

That's what makes it romantic. Every other married couple goes away on a honeymoon and for two weeks the bride knows just where the groom is, and vice versa. But us -- you never know where I am and I'm not sure where you are. That's Romance!
It's a... a complicated thing.
Hildy, if that's what you want, all right. We'll even go to -- how about Niagara Falls?
Niagara Falls? That's... a very ambitious plan.
Sure I do. And I'll tell you something else -- I'd like a baby.
A baby? That's... a very big question.
Sure, I can't last forever. I want a son I can train to take my place on this paper.
Train him? You're going to train him to take your place on this paper?
Well, if she looked like you -- Say! My brains and your looks -- that mightn't be such a bad combination.
What's the good of arguing about something that probably doesn't exist? Look, Hildy, I'm proposing to you. What do you say?
I don't want to rush you. Take a couple of seconds.

2429.content: It's just... you've been acting kinda strange, you know?
I don't know. You seem... different. You make weird jokes. Your accents changed. You don't even walk the same.
I'm sorry, I don't understand. Can you tell me more?
I can't put my finger on it, but everything's a bit off. Even the dinner tonight. It was beautiful, but...
Beautiful? What do you mean by beautiful?

24315.content: Karen.  I haven't been pleasant this weekend.
We've all seemed a little tense lately...
Come to think of it, I haven't been very pleasant for weeks. For that, I'm truly sorry. More than any two people I know, I don't want you and Lloyd to be angry with me...
We're never deeply angry, we just get sore. The way you do. We know you too well...
So many people - know me. I wish I did. I wish someone would tell be about me...
It's a strange thing, isn't it? To wish for someone to know you.

And what is that? Besides something spelled out in light bulbs, I mean. Besides something called temperament, which consists mostly of swooping about on a broomstick creaming at the top of my voice... infants behave the way I do, you know. They carry on and misbehave - they'd get drunk if they knew how - when they can't have what they want. When they feel unwanted and insecure - or unloved.

24324.content: More than anything in this world, I love Bill. And I want Bill. I want him to want me. But me. Not Margo Channing. And if I can't tell they apart - how can he?
Why should he - and why should you?
Because he's the only one who can truly understand my pain.
Margo. Bill is all of eight years younger than you.
It's a simple calculation. A difference of eight years. It's not a reflection of anything more than... a difference in the way we perceive time.
Not to you. Not to Bill.
I feel it, too. It's like a weight, a constant ache.

24360.content: Rosehill Avenue. No roses. No hill. And it's certainly not an avenue.
You need trees for an avenue.
There was talk of planting some when we first came.
I'm not sure. The records are... ambiguous.

24385.content: From what would I be running?
You're always after truth - on the stage. What about off?
Then face it. I have. Since that first night - here - in the dressing room.
When you told me that whatever I became, it would be because of you-
You hear all kinds of things.

24411.content: After you change, if you're not busy elsewhere, we can have supper.
I'd love to! Or should I pretend I'm busy?
Let's have a minimum of pretending. I'll want to do a column about you-
I'm not enough for a paragraph.

- perhaps more than one. There's so much I want to know. I've heard your story in bits and pieces... your home in Wisconsin, your tragic marriage, your financial attachment to Margo - it started in San Francisco, didn't it?  I say - your idolatry of Margo started in San Francisco, didn't it?
I'm not sure how to respond to that.
San Francisco. An oasis of civilization in the California desert. Tell me, do you share my high opinion of San Francisco?
I'm not sure how to respond to that.
And that memorable night when Margo first dazzled you from the stage - which theater was it in San Francisco? Was it - the Shubert?
I'm not sure how to respond to that.
A fine old theater, the Shubert. Full of tradition, untouched by the earthquake - so sorry - fire... by the way, what was your husband's name?
I'm not sure how to respond to that.

24421.content: - it's Addison, from start to finish, it drips with his brand of venom... taking advantage of a kid like that, twisting her words, making her say what he wanted her to say-
Where'd you get all that information?
She's been to see me, as a matter of fact she left just before you came in - you just missed her...
She wanted to explain about her interview, wanted to apologize to someone - and didn't dare face Margo...

24445.content: You know, I've always considered myself a very clever girl. Smart. Good head on my shoulders, that sort of thing, never the wrong word at the wrong time... but then, I'd never met Addison deWitt.  I remember once I had a tooth pulled. They gave me some anaesthetic - I don't remember the name - and it affected me in a strange way. I heard myself saying things I wasn't even thinking... as if my mind were someplace outside of my body, and couldn't control what I did or said-
- and you felt just like that talking to Addison.
In a way. You find yourself trying to say what you mean, but somehow the words change - and they become his words - and suddenly you're not saying what you mean, but what he means-
Do you expect me to believe that you didn't say any of those things - that they were all Addison?
No! I don't expect you to believe anything. Except that the responsibility is mine. And the disgrace.
- I understand. It's a heavy burden to carry.

You've really got a low opinion of me, haven't you? We'll I'll give you some pleasant news. I've been told off in no uncertain terms all over town. Miss Channing should be happy to hear that. To know how loyal her friends are - how much more loyal they are than she had a right to expect me to be...

24446.content: Tell me. How did your lunch turn out - with the man from Hollywood?
Some vague promises of a test, that's all - if a particular part should come along, one of those things-
But the raves about your performance-
It was... a bit of a mess.
Well. I think you're painting the picture a little darker than it is, really. If nothing else - and don't underestimate him - you have a powerful friend in Addison.
I... I don't know what to say.

24452.content: It's your crime scene now.  You can do what you want.
Well, just so you know.  I gave you guys the credit.
Well, just so you know, I don't care about that stuff.
I understand. But it's a really important piece of information.
You know, it's a really complex system.

24483.content: All three subjects are confirmed inside. Call off the house-to-house.  Okay, Dennis, I want to explain your situation --
You don't have to explain shit!  That Chinaman pulled a gun.  We wrestled for it.  That Chinaman shot himself.
Mr. Kim didn't make it, Dennis.  He died.
Dennis?  I want you to release those people.
You're not going to release them. They're all part of the plan.
We're not coming in there by force, okay? No one wants to hurt you.
You're not going to let them go. They're all part of the plan.

245.content: ...I've seen things.  In there.  Last night.  You did too.  Don't tell me you didn't.  You were crying like a baby.
You said the vision, the images.  They're just that.  Just pictures.  They can't hurt you.  That's what you always said.
All the more reason I should be here.
Please.  It's for your own good.
It's not about . It's about... the echoes.

24535.content: I couldn't find Jane.  She wasn't at the restaurant.
Okay, I'll call her. Let's try again.

24541.content: Slow down, Thomas.  Take it easy and talk to me.  Was your father shot?
Dennis hit him.  His head's all big and he won't wake up.  I'm really scared.
How about you and your sister?
I'm... I don't know. I've been running.

24545.content: He says that his father's hurt.
If we have a man dying in there, we'll have to go in.
They have security cameras.  Rooney would see you coming.
Did the boy say that any of them are in immediate danger?
No.  He said that his father's unconscious; he didn't say he was dying.
That's a good start. We need to understand the context of the situation.

24554.content: Don't tell anyone what you're doing, not Louise, not the other guys, not the Sheriffs.  You understand me, Larry?
Fuck guessing.  You keep your mouth shut.
You're a good boy. You're a good boy.

2456.content: You wouldn't believe me. I mean, people always say, "You wouldn't believe me", but in this case, it's not even worth trying.
I've seen some sickening shit. I don't blink twice anymore, especially in your case.
Let me ask you a question. Just a little one that's been gnawing at me for years.
On the bridge. How did you know that Tommy had your dog? That was no fucking hunch.

24563.content: Now I understand.  That helps.  I can make them understand that.
Fuck that!  You bastards will jump me!
If you won't let me come in, then put him outside.
You're being ridiculous. I'm not going to help you.
You've already helped yourself once, Dennis; be smart again.  If you save his life, it'll help when you get to court.

24602.content: In a few minutes the white phone is going to ring.  So let's get our shit straight before that happens.
You used to be a cop.  All of you used to be cops.  I can tell by the way you move.
Don't worry about what we used to be.
How do you people expect this to work? The Sheriffs have a Crisis Response Team here.
I asked you my name.  You just saw my commission slip.  What's my fucking name?
Think of me that way and you won't fuck up.  I'll handle the Sheriffs.

24690.content: Also with the reluctant compliments of Max Fabian.
Lloyd. I never have any, and he likes a couple of drinks after we finish - so he sent it up...
Some plain soda.  Lloyd must be expecting a record run in New Haven...
That's for tonight. You're invited. We're having everyone up after the performance.
Yes. We're having everyone up after the performance.

24705.content: She's always been so fantastically devoted to Lloyd. I would imagine that only death or destruction could keep her-
Addison, just a few minutes ago. When I told you this would be a night to remember - that it would bring me everything I wanted-
- something about an old road ending and a new one starting - paved with stars...
I didn't mean just the Theater.
- a moment of stillness, a quiet acceptance - the stars are a reminder of what was, and what will be.

24748.content: I'm sorry it is not Glenmorangie.
As long as it is scotch.  Your white friends have abandoned you, Paul.
The United Nations are still here.
The United Nations. Madmen are on the streets, Paul. But I will take care of you.  Your cellar is well-stocked, right?
Yes, General. I am glad you came by. I overheard something that I think you should know about.
I hear you. Let's hear it.
A discussion between an American Embassy official and a UN Colonel.
A discussion between an American Embassy official and a UN Colonel. It's a delicate situation. The Colonel is… intensely suspicious.
The American assured the colonel that they would watch everything.
The American assured the colonel that they would watch everything. A carefully constructed lie. He's looking for something, Paul. Something buried deep.

24749.content: Yes, they can photograph the epaulets on your shoulder.
And what will they do with these satellites?
The American said intervention is too costly, better to get photographic evidence and snatch up the high command.
What is the purpose of the satellites?
'Snatch them up and put on a war crimes trial. Lock them all away forever. No political risk, and big publicity.' That's what he said.  I thought I'd better tell you.

2475.content: What do you need it for? I don't get you lately.
Duly noted. Now I'm gonna ask you for one last favor.
Shhh. I need to concentrate on the blockbuster if I'm gonna destroy it.
Yes. It's a very important, very delicate, very... shiny thing.

24760.content: What do you take me for?
I don't know what I take you for anything...
It is possible - even conceivable - that you've confused me with that gang of backward children you've been playing tricks on - that you have the same contempt for me that you have for them?
I'm sure you mean something by that, Addison, but I don't know what...
Look closely, Eve, it's time you did. I am Addison deWitt. I'm nobody's fool. Least of all - yours.
Yes, you did. You still do.

24770.content: I have a confession. When we met...
Yes, when you worked as the nurse.
I had you transferred to Kigali.
I was assigned to the clinic.
I bribed the Minister of Health to have you transferred to Kigali.
That's... that's a difficult thing to say.
To be closer. So that I could marry you.
It was a lot of money.

24771.content: I still don't know what you're getting at. Right now I want to take my nap. It's important that I-
- it's important right now that we talk. Killer to killer.
Not with me, you're no champion. You're stepping way up in class.
Addison, will you please say what you have to say plainly and distinctly - and then get out so I can take my nap!
What do you mean by that?
What have you got to do with it?
Belong - to you? That sound medieval - something out of an old melodrama...
... taken it for granted? That you and I...

24787.content: They fired a rocket at us.
Yes. Where are the Rwandan police?
I ran out of bribes. Bizimungu took them away.
That explains it. I'm sorry to tell you this but we've heard rumors the Militia are getting ready to storm the hotel.
We will do our best. But we need to know who is the leader of the militia.

24795.content: You know what the Scottish call it?
Ishca Baha - the water of life. I went on a tour once of the finest single malt distillery in the world. Have you ever been to Scotland?
Wonderful country, wonderful golf. I wonder - will I ever go back? What do you think?

24819.content: Please don't have me arrested, please! I didn't steal anything - you can search me!
How did you get in here?

I hid outside in the hall till the maid came to turn down your bed. She must've forgot something and when she went to get it, she left the door open. I sneaked in and hid till she finished. Then I just looked around - and pretty soon I was afraid somebody'd notice the lights were on so I turned them off - and then I guess, I fell asleep.
Okay. Do you have any idea why I'm here?
I'm not sure. But I'm going to ask you a few questions.
About how you live, what kind of clothes you wear - what kind of perfume and books - things like that. You know the Eve Harrington clubs - that they've got in most of the girls' high schools?
Ours was one of the first. Erasmus Hall. I'm the president.
Erasmus Hall. I've heard of it.
Lots of actresses come from Brooklyn. Barbara Stanwyck, Susan Hayward - of course, they're just movie stars.

24825.content: Hold on, I've heard this before... but I can't remember the end.
So, the guy goes to Hell and the devil says, "do you smoke?" The guy say, "yeah"... the devil say, "great cause Tuesday is cigar night, sweetest Cuban cigars you ever had."
Shit, we really need to find some gas.
Then the devil asks, "do you drink?" Guy says, "yeah"... devil say, "wonderful, Wednesday is free drinks night, best booze you ever had... all made from the finest stuff."
So, the guy goes to the library and finds a book about...
I dunno... we'll ask around as we get closer. Man, I really don't want to run out of gas out here in the middle of Petticoat Junction, man.
Alright, alright. Let's just... let's just focus on getting to the next town.
And then, the guy finds a...

24830.content: Come on sleeping beauty, time to go to work.
No please, let me sit this one out.
Let's go. You're the one who wanted to be a photographer.
I'm not sure I can do that.
Too late. You're in for life, let's move it out Private Shutterbug.
I don't want to be a private shutterbug.
Aw, it ain't crap... it's... cute.  ...and really who are we to judge the artistic merit of the tin-can Mona Lisa?

24840.content: Hello...  ...hey Denise... what, what's wrong, did you break down?
